study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a polyherbal formulation containing Ginger (Zingiber officinale) could protect against diabetic cardiomyopathy in a rat model of diabetes.
results_summary: The polyherbal formulation, including Ginger, reduced markers of diabetic complications (e.g., blood glucose, plasma creatinine, oxidative stress enzymes) and improved antioxidant enzyme activities in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Ginger alone (polyherbal formulation administered).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of ginger-derived extracellular vesicles (GDEVs) conjugated with folic acid (FA-GDEVs) for treating rheumatoid arthritis (RA) by targeting M1 macrophages in inflamed joints.
results_summary: FA-GDEVs effectively targeted M1 macrophages, promoted polarization to the reparative M2 phenotype via the PI3K-AKT pathway, and significantly reduced RA symptoms in both in vitro and in vivo studies.
population_specificity: The study focused on RA, specifically targeting M1 macrophages in inflamed joints.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate ginger moxibustion as a safe and effective non-pharmacological therapy for treating diarrhea in COPD patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests ginger moxibustion is safe, effective in controlling diarrhea, has few side effects, and is well-accepted, making it an ideal alternative therapy for COPD patients with diarrhea.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) experiencing diarrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for preparing ginger-derived nanovesicles (GDNVs) loaded with curcumin (CG) and evaluate their therapeutic potential in treating ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: The study achieved high loading capacity (94.027%) and encapsulation efficiency (89.300%) for CG. In mice, CG showed superior anti-colitis activity compared to curcumin or GDNV alone, improving disease activity, colon length, and gut flora modulation.
population_specificity: Mice with ulcerative colitis (UC).
effective_dosage: Carrier-to-drug ratio (GDNV:CUR) of 1:1, ultrasound time of 3 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of dried ginger extract (DGE) on H. pylori growth and its key virulence factor urease, as well as to identify the active compounds and mechanism of action.
results_summary: DGE inhibited the growth of four H. pylori strains with MIC values ranging from 0.05 to 1.50 mg mL-1 and showed higher inhibitory activity on H. pylori urease (HPU) than on jack bean urease (JBU). The mechanism involved interaction with sulfhydryl groups and Ni2+, and the inhibition was reversible.
population_specificity: In vitro study (H. pylori strains: ATCC 43504, NCTC 26695, SS1, and ICDC 111001)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-fibrotic potential of a nutraceutical blend containing ginger extract, formulated as both emulsion and nanoemulsion, in a rat model of liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that the nutraceutical blend, particularly in nanoemulsion form, significantly improved liver function, enhanced antioxidant capacity, reduced lipid peroxidation, and modulated fibrogenic markers, leading to reduced liver fibrosis. The nanoemulsion showed superior efficacy compared to the emulsion.
population_specificity: Male albino rats with induced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MeJA (methyl jasmonate) could delay the deterioration of external quality and volatile compound loss in ginger during storage, thereby maintaining its flavor quality.
results_summary: MeJA treatment effectively retarded weight loss, moisture reduction, texture softening, and color darkening in ginger rhizomes during storage. It also slowed the loss of volatile compounds, particularly terpenes, and enhanced the expression of terpene-related genes, preserving the spicy aroma of ginger.
population_specificity: Ginger rhizomes (postharvest storage)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction between Licorice and dried ginger decoction (LGD), its component glycyrrhetinic acid (GA), and siglec-1 in alleviating inflammation and mitochondrial dysfunction in COPD.
results_summary: LGD treatment significantly reduced lung injury and inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, IL-8) in COPD rats and cells. GA was found to target siglec-1, reducing ROS production and improving mitochondrial function.
population_specificity: COPD rat model and alveolar macrophage NR8383 cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of ginger-processed Anemarrhenae Rhizoma in treating cough due to cold and dampness in the lung, providing a modern pharmacological basis for this therapy.
results_summary: Ginger-processed Anemarrhenae Rhizoma reduced lung tissue pathological changes, attenuated inflammatory cell infiltration, lowered inflammatory cytokine levels, and down-regulated MAPK14 and MMP3 expression, outperforming raw Anemarrhenae Rhizoma. The study suggests it inhibits inflammation via IL-17 and TNF signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Mouse model of acute bronchitis induced by smoke plus cold stimulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ginger root extract (GRE) on cognitive impairment and the expression of Nrf2, GPX4, and SLC7A11 in aluminum-exposed rats.
results_summary: GRE treatment improved cognitive function, preserved neuronal integrity, maintained mitochondrial structure, and regulated antioxidant levels in aluminum-exposed rats, likely through the Nrf2/GPX4/SLC7A11 signaling pathway. Medium and high doses of GRE showed the most significant enhancements in cognitive tests and antioxidant markers.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats exposed to aluminum.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 400 mg/kg GRE, administered once daily, five days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of ginger, 6-gingerol, and zingerone in preventing and treating chemotherapy-induced organ toxicity, including both ferroptotic and non-ferroptotic mechanisms.
results_summary: Ginger extract, 6-gingerol, and zingerone were found to mitigate non-ferroptotic oxidative inflammation, apoptosis, and mitochondrial dysfunction caused by chemotherapy, but their effects on chemotherapy-induced ferroptosis remain unclear and require further investigation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies referenced, but no human population details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of ginger extract as an alternative, effective, and safe treatment for colon cancer by examining its cytotoxic effects and impact on autophagy and apoptosis pathways.
results_summary: Ginger demonstrated significant cytotoxicity against Caco-2 colon cancer cells, altered autophagy-related genes (Bectin1, Atg5, PTEN), and increased caspase-3 activity, promoting apoptosis. It also modulated pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-8), suggesting potential anti-cancer effects.
population_specificity: Caco-2 colon cancer cells (in vitro study).
study_duration: Not specified (assessed after 24 hours for cytokine levels).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and assess the feasibility of an exercise protocol within the GINGER multicomponent lifestyle intervention for individuals with subjective cognitive decline (SCD).
results_summary: The exercise protocol was feasible, with high adherence and satisfaction among participants, and improved physical outcomes such as balance, aerobic capacity, and strength. The intervention demonstrated reliability across testers' assessments.
population_specificity: Individuals aged >55 years with subjective cognitive decline (SCD).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise intervention included aerobic, strengthening, balance, and dual-task exercises, delivered 3 times/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effects of ginger exosome-like nanoparticles (GELNs) on periodontitis and their underlying mechanisms of action.
results_summary: GELNs improved periodontal clinical parameters and pathology in rats, enhanced proliferation and migration of periodontal ligament fibroblasts, and reduced oxidative stress by inhibiting the NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: SD rats with induced periodontitis and in vitro periodontal ligament fibroblasts (PDLFs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger ethanolic extract could alleviate Alzheimer's disease symptoms by modulating gut microbiota activity, reducing neuroinflammation, and improving cognitive function in a rat model.
results_summary: Ginger extract improved gut microbiota activity, increased SCFA levels, reduced neuroinflammatory markers (TNF-α and IL-1β), decreased hippocampal cell death and amyloid plaque deposition, and enhanced learning and memory performance in rats.
population_specificity: Female rats with induced Alzheimer's disease via ovariectomy and D-galactose injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of exosomes derived from healthy menstrual blood-derived stem cells (C-exos) and ginger root exosomes (P-exos) on endometriotic mesenchymal stem cells (E-MenSCs).
results_summary: Ginger exosomes (P-exos) reduced inflammation-related genes (IL-6, IL-1β), decreased migration/invasion markers (MMP-9, VEGF), and lowered the apoptosis ratio (BAX/BCL2) in E-MenSCs, showing effects comparable to C-exos.
population_specificity: Endometriosis patients (specifically, their menstrual blood-derived stem cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate ginger juice's ability to reduce Ochratoxin A (OTA) toxicity and its effects on hepatocellular carcinoma cells and zebrafish embryos.
results_summary: Ginger juice (2.5% v/v) reduced OTA by 95.63%, following first-order kinetics, and mitigated OTA-induced toxicity in HepG2 cells and zebrafish embryos, reversing teratogenic effects and improving viability.
population_specificity: In vitro (HepG2 cells) and in vivo (zebrafish embryos).
interactions: Salt (>2.5%) and temperature (>40°C) compromised OTA reduction activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available knowledge about the ameliorative properties of ginger compounds in reducing clinical symptoms of allergic diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights ginger's anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and immunomodulatory properties, suggesting its potential to alleviate allergic disease symptoms with minimal side effects. However, specific clinical outcomes or statistical results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general allergic disease population inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of ginger extract-loaded PVA nanofibers as a localized treatment for human skin melanoma B16F10 cells.
results_summary: The ginger extract-loaded membranes suppressed melanoma cell growth and migration in a dose- and time-dependent manner, modulated Ras/ERK and PI3K/AKT signaling pathways, and showed no toxicity in liver or skin tissues in a rat model.
population_specificity: Human skin melanoma B16F10 cells and rat models for tissue toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-leishmanial efficacy of green-synthesized silver nanoparticles (Ag-NPs) derived from ginger extract against *Leishmania infantum* and *Leishmania tropica* in vitro.
results_summary: The study found that Ag-NPs significantly reduced the proliferation of *L. infantum* and *L. tropica* promastigotes, with higher concentrations (e.g., 80 ppm) showing greater lethality. Flow cytometry revealed apoptosis rates of 67.1% and 41.9% for *L. infantum* and *L. tropica*, respectively.
population_specificity: In vitro study on *Leishmania infantum* and *Leishmania tropica* promastigotes.
effective_dosage: Effective doses included 80 ppm and 40 ppm after 48 and 72 hours, respectively; lower doses (0.312 ppm and 0.156 ppm) had minimal effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger-derived exosome-like nanovesicles (GDN) could alleviate osteoarthritis (OA) progression in chondrocytes, a rat model, and human OA cartilage explants.
results_summary: GDN promoted cartilage anabolism, reduced oxidative stress in TBHP-induced chondrocytes and OA rats, and showed protective effects in human OA cartilage explants, with the Nrf2 pathway implicated in these effects.
population_specificity: TBHP-induced chondrocytes, posttraumatic OA rat model, and ex vivo cultured human OA cartilage explants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of dietary ginger preparations during pregnancy and lactation, focusing on maternal and neonatal outcomes.
results_summary: The majority of meta-analyses found ginger significantly improved nausea in pregnancy compared to placebo or showed equivalence to conventional treatments, with no evidence of significant adverse effects. However, the included studies had substantial heterogeneity and were of low quality.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger extracts could prevent cardiovascular disease initiation by inhibiting LDL oxidation and reducing foam cell formation.
results_summary: The study found that ginger extracts, particularly fractions D and E, exhibited antioxidative effects and showed promise in preventing CVD by inhibiting LDL oxidation and reducing foam cell formation. Further research is needed to identify the active compounds and their mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal models based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ginger on clinical and paraclinical features in outpatients with COVID-19.
results_summary: Ginger did not significantly improve viral clearance, oxygen saturation, body temperature, or respiratory rate compared to placebo, but it reduced pulmonary infiltrate and showed a safe adverse event profile.
population_specificity: Outpatients with confirmed COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of steamed ginger extract (GGE03) in improving joint pain and managing mild knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that GGE03 significantly reduced pain and improved osteoarthritis symptoms compared to placebo, with no reported adverse effects. The results suggest GGE03 is effective and safe for managing knee OA.
population_specificity: 100 subjects with mild knee osteoarthritis
effective_dosage: 0.48 g/day as GGE03 (1.6 g total product daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of Ginger-Derived Extracellular Vesicles (GDEVs) on hair loss and elucidate their mechanism of action in treating alopecia.
results_summary: GDEVs reduced inflammation and promoted hair follicle stem cell proliferation, leading to rapid recovery of balding areas and healthier hair growth in alopecia model mice. The study identified 13 specific ingredients in GDEVs pivotal for hair proliferation.
population_specificity: Alopecia model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidative effects of ginger extract in human skin cell cultures and its clinical efficacy in alleviating atopic dermatitis symptoms when combined with synthetic CBD.
results_summary: Ginger extract demonstrated potent anti-inflammatory and antioxidative effects in vitro, associated with elevated endocannabinoid levels. In the clinical trial, the combination product (BNO 3731) significantly reduced itch intensity by 55% and improved skin parameters in AD patients.
population_specificity: 44 AD patients (adults and children)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of sonication-assisted extraction on the physico-chemical properties, antioxidant capacity, and antibacterial effectiveness of dry ginger extract.
results_summary: The sonicated ginger extract showed a 28% increase in total phenolic content compared to traditional methods, exhibited 56.0% DPPH radical scavenging activity, and demonstrated potent antibacterial effects against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. Strong correlations were found between phenolic content and antioxidant activity, as well as volatile compounds and antibacterial action.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of oral ginger supplementation in reducing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) in children.
results_summary: Ginger significantly reduced both acute and delayed CINV with a number needed to treat (NNT) of 2-4, and no adverse effects were reported. However, high heterogeneity was noted in cancer treatment, chemotherapy regimen, ginger dosing, and processing.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oral and external administration of cedrol (CE) from ginger on hair regeneration in alopecia areata mice and clarify its hair growth mechanism.
results_summary: CE oral administration (CE-OA) showed superior results in promoting hair growth, reducing hair follicle damage, and alleviating immunosuppression compared to external administration (CE-EA). CE regulated the JAK3/STAT3 pathway, activated Wnt3α/β-catenin, and reduced oxidative stress, reversing alopecia areata.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 alopecia areata mice induced by cyclophosphamide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral ginger supplementation on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of ginger supplementation on fasting blood glucose (FBS) or glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), though two individual studies reported significant reductions in FBS. The overall impact on glycemic control in T2DM was not statistically significant when results were pooled.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) participating in randomized clinical trials.
effective_dosage: 1.2 to 2g/day, administered twice daily in capsule form.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel colon-targeted oral drug delivery system using ginger-derived extracellular vesicles (EVs) and porous ZIF-8 nanoparticles to deliver TNF-α siRNA for ulcerative colitis therapy.
results_summary: The study found that ginger EVs exhibited strong colon and macrophage targeting, resistance to stomach acid degradation, and anti-inflammatory effects via 6-shogaol. The composite nanoparticle (EVs@ZIF-8@siRNA) significantly reduced TNF-α levels in colonic tissue and promoted intestinal barrier repair by regulating gut microbiota in UC mice.
population_specificity: UC mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of ginger on diabetic cardiomyopathy by evaluating its impact on oxidative damage, inflammation, apoptosis, and cardiac gene expression in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Ginger extract (100 mg/kg) significantly moderated oxidative damage, inflammation, and apoptosis markers in diabetic rats, improved cardiac gene expression (TRPM2, TRPV2, NF-kappaB, Bax, Cas-3, Bcl2, Nrf-2), and showed enhanced therapeutic effects when combined with omega-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with type 2 diabetes induced by high-fat diet and STZ.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal extraction conditions for enhancing bioactive components in ginger leaves and evaluate their antioxidant capacity and potential immune-boosting effects.
results_summary: The study found that optimized extraction conditions improved yield and antioxidant capacity (except for total phenolic content) and increased nitric oxide and cytokine levels in macrophage cells, suggesting potential immune benefits.
population_specificity: In vitro (macrophage cells)
effective_dosage: Enzyme concentration of 0.1% (v/v), liquid-solid ratio of 33.939 mL/g, extraction time of 4 h

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ginger polysaccharides (GP) on growth performance, immunity, intestinal microbiota, and disease resistance in crucian carp.
results_summary: Dietary GP significantly improved growth performance, immunity, antioxidant capacity, and liver health in crucian carp, while also regulating intestinal microbiota and reducing mortality from Aeromonas hydrophila infection. The 0.4% GP group showed the most notable benefits.
population_specificity: Crucian carp (a species of fish)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ginger-partitioned moxibustion combined with ringheaded thumb-tack needle stimulation in preventing and treating chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV) in patients with malignant tumors.
results_summary: The study found that ginger-partitioned moxibustion combined with needle stimulation significantly reduced nausea and vomiting compared to the control group (ondansetron hydrochloride tablets) after the 2nd and 3rd day of treatment. It also improved TCM syndrome scores but showed no significant difference in KPS scores or blood/liver/kidney function markers between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with malignant tumors undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Ginger-partitioned moxibustion combined with needle stimulation once daily for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic efficacy of 8-Gingerol, a ginger constituent, on acute lung injury (ALI) induced by hemorrhagic shock in rats.
results_summary: 8-Gingerol reduced pulmonary edema, inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell apoptosis in lung tissues, and modulated MAPK and Nrf2/HO-1 pathways, showing promise for treating HS-induced ALI.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats with hemorrhagic shock-induced ALI.
effective_dosage: 15 or 30 mg/kg administered via intraperitoneal injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical research landscape on ginger, focusing on its pharmacological effects and studied health-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study identified 89 clinical trials on ginger, with treatment objectives being predominant (47.2%). Ginger showed potential benefits in areas such as antiemetic activity, analgesic function, and blood pressure variation, but a significant gap in reported final results was noted.
population_specificity: Not specified (various clinical trial populations)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant effects of ginger leaves (GLs) and predict their molecular targets using network pharmacology.
results_summary: The study identified nine major bioactive compounds in GLs, with astragalin showing the highest connectivity in antioxidant-related pathways. GLs demonstrated significant antioxidant activity in DPPH and ABTS assays, suggesting potential for development as antioxidants.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and computational analysis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immunomodulatory action of ginger's active components and the molecular mechanisms that reduce asthma, focusing on its efficacy in treating allergic asthma.
results_summary: Ginger and its active ingredients demonstrated anti-asthmatic effects, including suppression of mast cell histamine production and notable reduction in allergic responses in animal models. The findings suggest potential benefits but require further validation for human treatments.
population_specificity: Mouse model of asthma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chitosan and beeswax coatings in preserving the physicochemical properties of fresh ginger during storage.
results_summary: Coating ginger with chitosan and beeswax slowed changes in moisture, phenolic content, and other properties during storage. The best results were achieved with 3% chitosan followed by 6% beeswax, which maintained quality for six months, especially at 18°C.
population_specificity: Fresh ginger samples (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: 1.5% and 3.5% chitosan coatings, followed by 3% and 6% beeswax coatings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the hypoglycemic effects of ginger (Zingiber officinale) in rats with induced type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Ginger administration significantly increased serum insulin and high-density lipoprotein levels while reducing fasting blood glucose, total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein, and glycated hemoglobin levels in diabetic rats. Liver glycogen levels also showed a statistically significant increase.
population_specificity: Male adult albino rats with induced type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (ginger powder administered in varying amounts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ginger for pain management in primary dysmenorrhea through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Ginger was notably more effective than placebo in reducing both the intensity and duration of pain in dysmenorrhea, with no significant differences compared to NSAIDs or exercise. The findings were limited by risk of bias in included studies and unclear risk-benefit ratio.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age with primary dysmenorrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential antiviral compounds in ginger, particularly (6)-gingerdiacetate, and assess their ability to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 infection by targeting viral proteins and host immune responses.
results_summary: The study identified (6)-gingerdiacetate as a promising antiviral compound in ginger, showing strong binding interactions with key viral proteins (Mpro, RBD, ACE2) and confirmed its presence in ginger hydroalcoholic extract, which exhibited potent antiviral activity (IC50 of 2.727 μg/ml). Computational and experimental results suggest ginger may enhance immune response and block viral entry.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and computational study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (hydroalcoholic extract concentration used in assays).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which the herb pair Coptidis Rhizoma-ginger may exert anti-colon cancer effects.
results_summary: The study identified 229 intersection targets and 40 key genes involved in colon cancer prevention, with the herb pair modulating pathways like PI3K-Akt and HIF-1 signaling. Molecular docking validated strong binding affinity between active compounds and key targets, suggesting potential therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study, no human or animal subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a gastro-retentive raft-forming liquid formulation incorporating ginger extract solid dispersion (GE-SD) to enhance the prolonged delivery of 6-gingerol for gastric ulcer treatment.
results_summary: The GE-SD-loaded raft-forming formulations demonstrated rapid floating behavior, sustained release of 6-gingerol (>70% over 8 hours), anti-inflammatory activity (IC50 = 5.13 ± 0.07 μg/mL), cytotoxic effects on gastric adenocarcinoma cells (IC50 = 17.45 ± 0.29 μg/mL), and enhanced fibroblast migration in a scratch wound model.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using RAW 264.7 macrophage cells, AGS human gastric adenocarcinoma cells, and L929 mouse fibroblasts.
effective_dosage: Not specified for human use; in vitro concentrations included IC50 values of 5.13 μg/mL (anti-inflammatory) and 17.45 μg/mL (cytotoxic).
study_duration: Not specified for human use; in vitro observations over 8 hours for release studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the cytotoxic effects of siphonochilone (a component of Siphonochilus aethiopicus, not Ginger) on various cancer cell lines and its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Siphonochilone exhibited significant cytotoxic effects on pancreatic, breast, lung, colon, and liver cancer cell lines, with IC50 values ranging from 22 to 124 μM. Cell death was mediated by apoptosis via the mitochondrial pathway and reactive oxygen species generation.
population_specificity: Cancer cell lines (pancreatic, breast, lung, colon, liver).
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 22.03 μM (MCF7) and 39.03 μM (PANC1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger supplements could relieve chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV).
results_summary: Ginger capsules combined with standard antiemetics significantly reduced severe acute nausea and high-grade vomiting. Ginger-partitioned moxibustion also alleviated mild and severe vomiting, with minimal adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing chemotherapy (highly emetogenic regimens).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ginger capsules and ginger-partitioned moxibustion used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of ginger-derived silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) for anticancer and antibacterial applications, focusing on their phytochemical, antioxidant, antibacterial, and cytotoxic properties.
results_summary: The study found that ginger-derived AgNPs exhibited significant antioxidant and antibacterial activity against multiple bacterial species, including drug-resistant strains, and demonstrated promising cytotoxicity against Vero cell lines at low concentrations (0.6-6 μg/mL). The nanoparticles were also confirmed to be non-toxic, eco-friendly, and suitable for large-scale production.
population_specificity: In vitro (Vero cell lines and bacterial species including Escherichia coli, Bacillus subtilis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Staphylococcus aureus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biocontrol and plant growth-promoting effects of endophytic bacteria (strain K3) isolated from ginger rhizomes.
results_summary: The study found that strain K3 significantly inhibited the growth of pathogenic fungi and bacteria, reduced soft rot incidence in ginger, and improved plant growth metrics such as shoot length and rhizome yield. Enzymatic activity and stress-related enzyme levels were also enhanced in K3-treated plants.
population_specificity: Ginger plants (Zingiber officinale) in greenhouse and field trial conditions.
effective_dosage: Cell-free extract concentrations of 2.5% and 5% were used for in vitro testing; K3 strain was applied directly to plants in greenhouse and field trials (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: 180 days for field trial (greenhouse duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effect of garlic and ginger on a mice model of breast cancer, focusing on tumor size, antioxidant levels, and gene expression.
results_summary: Ginger (especially at 500 mg/kg) significantly reduced tumor size, increased glutathione reductase and peroxidase levels, and decreased HER2 expression. The combined use of garlic and ginger also increased PTEN expression.
population_specificity: Female mice weighing 18-20 g with induced breast cancer.
effective_dosage: 100 and 500 mg/kg ginger extract, administered intraperitoneally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of black ginger (Kaempferia parviflora) extract on the quality of frozen/thawed rooster semen and its fertility potential.
results_summary: Sperm concentration, motility, and fertility improved significantly with 150-200 mg/kg KP extract, while lipid peroxidation (MDA levels) decreased. The optimal dosage for sperm quality was 200 mg/kg, but 150 mg/kg was sufficient for maintaining post-thaw fertility.
population_specificity: Thai native roosters (Pradu Hang Dum, 42 weeks old).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize DPP-4 inhibitory peptides from wheat gluten hydrolysates prepared using ginger protease, assessing their potential for type 2 diabetes therapy.
results_summary: Ginger protease-prepared wheat gluten hydrolysates showed the highest DPP-4 inhibitory activity, with specific peptides (PPFS, APFGL, PPFW) exhibiting potent inhibition. These peptides interacted with key DPP-4 structural elements and demonstrated stability, suggesting therapeutic or functional food applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the analgesic efficacy of ginger ingredient 8-Shogaol (8S) in inflammatory pain and morphine tolerance, and to explore its mechanism via TRPV1 activation.
results_summary: 8S effectively reduced nociceptive behaviors in mice, antagonized morphine tolerance, and activated TRPV1, leading to channel desensitization. The study identified key binding sites for 8S-TRPV1 interaction, suggesting 8S as a potential treatment for inflammatory pain.
population_specificity: Mice (genetic and electrophysiology models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of steam-processed ginger extract (GGE) with conventional ginger extract (GE) in alleviating metabolic syndrome-related symptoms, particularly obesity and diabetes.
results_summary: GGE showed superior antioxidant capacity, α-glucosidase inhibitory activity, suppression of adipocyte differentiation, and lipid accumulation compared to GE. In high-fat-diet-fed mice, GGE improved biochemical profiles and downregulated genes related to fat synthesis.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet-fed mice (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gingerols-enriched ginger (GEG) supplementation could alleviate diabetic neuropathic pain (DNP) by modulating gut microbiota, mitochondrial function, and neuroinflammation in rats.
results_summary: GEG supplementation reduced mechanical hypersensitivity and anxio-depressive behavior in DNP rats, improved gut microbiome composition, suppressed neuroinflammation markers, and enhanced mitochondrial function.
population_specificity: Male rats with induced diabetic neuropathic pain (high-fat diet + streptozotocin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory properties of a dental varnish containing ginger and rosemary extracts mediated by titanium dioxide nanoparticles.
results_summary: The study found concentration-dependent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects in the test group compared to the control, with increased inhibition observed in the BSA assay at higher titanium dioxide nanoparticle concentrations. The bioactive compounds in ginger and rosemary contributed to these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using Bovine Serum Albumin and membrane stabilization assays).
effective_dosage: 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 μL concentrations of titanium dioxide nanoparticles with ginger and rosemary extracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effect of rhizobacterial isolates and ginger powder extract (GPE) in controlling early blight disease in tomato plants.
results_summary: The study found that combinations of bacterial isolates and GPE significantly inhibited the mycelial growth of Alternaria solani, with St-149D + GPE showing the highest inhibition (76.9%). GPE also enhanced seed germination and activated defense-related enzymes in tomato plants.
population_specificity: Tomato plants infected with Alternaria solani (early blight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger supplementation alters the fecal microbiome in a way consistent with its colorectal cancer-inhibitory effects in adults previously diagnosed with colorectal adenomas.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation did not significantly affect overall microbial diversity but led to decreased abundances of CRC-associated taxa (Akkermansia, Bacteroides, and Ruminococcus). The study concluded that ginger has a limited effect on the gut microbiome in this population.
population_specificity: Adults previously diagnosed with colorectal adenomas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ginger compounds (6-gingerol and 6-shogaol) on the functionality of human dendritic cells (DCs) and their anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that 6-gingerol and 6-shogaol inhibited dendritic cell activation, cytokine production, and T cell stimulatory ability, with 6-shogaol showing greater potency. These effects were mediated through suppression of NF-kB, MAPK, and mTOR pathways, and 6-shogaol additionally activated AMPK and NRF2 pathways.
population_specificity: Primary human monocyte-derived dendritic cells (moDCs).
effective_dosage: Dose-dependent effects were observed, but specific dosages are not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of ginger volatile oil (GVO) on the growth of MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells and gut microbiota diversity in the presence of bisphenol A (BPA).
results_summary: GVO reduced breast cancer tumor volume and weight, with significant effects at high doses (P < 0.05). It also restored gut microbiota diversity and altered the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio, increasing beneficial bacteria like Lactobacillus and Alistipes.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c Nude (nu/nu) mice with induced triple-negative breast cancer.
effective_dosage: 0.25 mL/kg, 0.5 mL/kg, and 1 mL/kg, administered once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and analyze randomized controlled trials (RCTs) assessing the effects of ginger on body weight and body composition parameters.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant association between ginger supplementation and reductions in body weight, BMI, waist circumference, and percent body fat, with an effective dose of 2 g/d and duration longer than 8 weeks. The certainty of evidence was low to very low for these outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults (1309 participants across 27 RCTs)
effective_dosage: 2 g/d (effective dose for body mass reduction)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review literature on ginger's pharmacodynamic components and mechanisms for colorectal cancer (CRC) prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Ginger exhibits anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, immunoregulatory, and anticancer properties, including inhibiting CRC cell proliferation, inducing apoptosis, and enhancing chemotherapeutic drug effects. The study summarizes these mechanisms from clinical, animal, and in vitro studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review encompassing clinical, animal, and in vitro studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the fungicidal effects of benzalkonium chloride (BAC) and benzethonium chloride (BEC) on Fusarium solani and Fusarium oxysporum as alternatives to common chemical fungicides for treating ginger soft rot.
results_summary: The study found that BAC and BEC at 100 mg/L concentration nearly completely inactivated spores of F. solani and F. oxysporum, with minimal spore regrowth observed in soil, suggesting their potential as effective alternatives to traditional fungicides for soil disinfection.
population_specificity: Diseased ginger plants infected with F. solani and F. oxysporum.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/L concentration of BAC and BEC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of zerumbone from bitter ginger in improving quality of life and symptom control in cancer patients with no treatment options.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in quality of life (global, activity, social, and emotional dimensions), anxiety, depression, and fatigue, with low toxicity reported. However, no significant changes were observed in weight or sleep quality.
population_specificity: 35 cancer patients (mean age 68 years, 64% men) with no treatment options.
effective_dosage: 400 mg of zerumbone twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ultrasonic pre-treatment on moisture removal, rehydration capability, color retention, and bioactive compound retention in ginger during convective drying.
results_summary: Increasing sonication duration and air temperature reduced drying time and energy consumption while improving rehydration capability and color retention. The main volatile component (α-Zingiberene) was unaffected, but phenolic content and antioxidant activity slightly decreased with longer sonication. Optimal conditions were 66°C, 3 m/s air velocity, and 20 min sonication.
population_specificity: Ginger slabs (not human subjects)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on drying parameters)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of ginger, among other aromatic herbs and spices in the Mediterranean Diet, on glycemic control in subjects with Type 2 Diabetes.
results_summary: Ginger significantly improved fasting glucose levels in T2DM subjects, achieving a decrease of approximately 17 mg/dL. It also showed a significant improvement in glycated hemoglobin and a significant decrease in insulin levels.
population_specificity: Subjects with Type 2 Diabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic roles of ginger and its bioactive compounds in sepsis by analyzing existing literature.
results_summary: The study found that ginger and its bioactive elements (gingerol, shogaol, gingerdione, zingerone) demonstrated effectiveness in sepsis by suppressing pro-inflammatory cytokines, downregulating immune response, and protecting against organ failure in experimental and animal models. Human clinical trials were recommended to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Experimental and animal models (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Gingerol (1-300 µg/mL or 1-100 mg/kg), shogaol (0.2-100 µg/mL or 10-40 mg/kg), gingerdione (1-100 µg/mL), zingerone (2-20 µM).
study_duration: 24 hours to 14 days, depending on the compound.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) combined with dietary supplements, including ginger, on body fat loss, metabolic health, and aerobic capacity in adults with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that combining HIIT with dietary supplements like ginger enhanced body fat reduction, metabolic health, and aerobic capacity, though the combination was not deemed necessary for achieving benefits. Ginger's specific effects were not detailed separately from other supplements.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of ginger in the context of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding ginger's effects.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD, often associated with obesity, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ginger supplementation could alleviate common gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS).
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly reduced the frequency and severity of constipation, nausea, bloating, and abdominal pain compared to placebo in RRMS patients. The effects were statistically significant or near-significant for most symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) experiencing gastrointestinal symptoms.
effective_dosage: 500 mg ginger supplement taken 3 times daily with main meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ginger (Zingiber Officinale) in managing nausea and vomiting induced by cisplatin and radiotherapy in cervical cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that ginger supplementation (250 mg or 500 mg) did not reduce the intensity of acute or late nausea and vomiting compared to placebo, with the 250 mg group even showing an 8.0% higher chance of nausea (though not statistically significant).
population_specificity: Patients with cervical cancer undergoing cisplatin (40 mg/m²) and radiotherapy, aged over 18, able to swallow capsules.
study_duration: Measured at baseline, 7 days after first dose, and weekly during treatment breaks (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of adjuvant ginger compared with placebo on chemotherapy-induced nausea-related quality of life and CINV-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study found clinically relevant evidence favoring ginger in improving nausea-related quality of life, with no significant adverse events reported. Ginger supplementation was deemed safe and effective as an adjuvant to antiemetic medications for CINV.
population_specificity: Chemotherapy-naïve adults scheduled to receive moderately to highly emetogenic chemotherapy at two hospitals in Australia.
effective_dosage: 84 mg/day active gingerols/shogaols (four standardized ginger capsules daily).
study_duration: 5 days per chemotherapy cycle for cycles 1 through 3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a ginger-based gastrointestinal supplement (GI-Ease) as an alternative to simethicone for reducing bubbles during colonoscopy procedures.
results_summary: In 98% of cases (112/114), the ginger-based supplement effectively reduced bubbles, allowing visualization of the gastrointestinal tract without any reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colonoscopy procedures with substantial bubbles impeding mucosal wall visibility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a standardized ginger root powder on gastrointestinal bacteria composition and associated outcomes in healthy adults compared to placebo.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation increased the relative abundance of certain bacteria (e.g., Actinobacteria, Parabacteroides) and improved indigestion symptoms but did not affect alpha or beta diversity, bowel function, mood, or quality of life. No moderate or severe adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged 18-30 years (71% female, mean age 25 ± 3 years).
effective_dosage: 1.2 g/d (4 capsules totaling 84 mg/d of active gingerols/shogaols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize global dietary supplement use, including ginger, during the first two years of the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Ginger was among the natural/herbal products widely reported as used during the pandemic, primarily to strengthen the immune system and prevent COVID-19 infection. The study did not provide specific efficacy data for ginger.
population_specificity: Large population surveys across 11 countries and 3 continents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ginger supplementation on lipid profile components (TG, TC, LDL-C, HDL-C) in humans, particularly in diabetic patients.
results_summary: Ginger intake significantly reduced TC and TG levels but had no significant effect on HDL-C and LDL-C. It was more effective in lowering TG in obese and diabetic subjects, and higher doses of ginger were associated with greater reductions in TC.
population_specificity: Humans, with specific focus on obese and diabetic subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ginger supplementation on prooxidant-antioxidant balance, glycemic management, and renal function in diabetic hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, insulin resistance (HOMA-IR), and serum urea levels compared to placebo. It also decreased serum creatinine and prooxidant-antioxidant balance within the ginger group, though these effects were not significant between groups.
population_specificity: Diabetic hemodialysis patients with end-stage renal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ginger supplementation as an adjuvant treatment for alleviating chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV).
results_summary: The study systematically reviewed 23 RCTs and found that ginger supplementation was compared to placebo or antiemetic agents, with subgroup analyses for acute and delayed CINV. The results indicated a reduction in the incidence of acute nausea.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing chemotherapy experiencing nausea and vomiting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential anti-inflammatory properties of ginger in addressing common inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: The abstract suggests ginger has anti-inflammatory properties, but specific outcomes or effects are not detailed. The study implies potential benefits for inflammatory conditions but lacks concrete results.
population_specificity: Not specified (general inflammatory disease context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ginger supplementation on lipid profile and body weight through a meta-analysis of randomized, controlled trials.
results_summary: Ginger consumption significantly improved lipid profile (reducing triglycerides, cholesterol, and LDL while increasing HDL) and decreased BMI, though the effect on body weight was not statistically significant. Higher doses (>1500 mg/d) and longer durations (>8 weeks) were more effective for weight control.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of multiple randomized, controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effect of a polyherbal supplement containing ginger (ReWin(d)) on gut microbiota diversity and related biomarkers in recreational athletes.
results_summary: ReWin(d) supplementation slightly increased gut microbiota diversity and showed changes in the relative abundance of certain microbial taxa, though specific details on ginger's isolated effects were not provided.
population_specificity: Recreational athletes who practiced physical activity at least three times weekly.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentioned as part of the polyherbal supplement ReWin(d)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of ginger supplementation on metabolic profile in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM) through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant reductions in fasting blood sugar (FBS) and HbA1c levels following ginger supplementation, indicating potential benefits for metabolic control in T2DM patients. The results were based on pooled data from 10 randomized clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ginger supplementation on inflammatory biomarkers (hs-CRP, TNF-α, and IL-6) in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly reduced hs-CRP, TNF-α, and IL-6 levels in patients with T2DM, though the reductions were relatively small and clinical relevance remains uncertain. The included studies had a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of OLNP-06, a ginger extract, in treating functional dyspepsia (FD) using a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
results_summary: The study found that 79% of subjects receiving OLNP-06 showed significant improvements in clinical endpoints, including symptom elimination, compared to 21% in the placebo group, with an excellent safety profile.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-55 years diagnosed with functional dyspepsia per ROME III criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ginger supplementation on biomarkers of oxidative stress, specifically glutathione peroxidase (GPx), malondialdehyde (MDA), and total antioxidant capacity (TAC).
results_summary: Ginger significantly increased GPx and reduced MDA but did not significantly alter TAC. Greater reductions in MDA were observed with lower doses (≤1 g), shorter durations (<12 weeks), and in participants aged ≥30. TAC improvements were seen with higher doses, longer durations (≥12 weeks), and larger sample sizes.
population_specificity: Participants included both genders, with specific effects noted for those aged ≥30.
effective_dosage: ≤1 g and higher doses (exact frequency not specified).
study_duration: Varied, with some trials lasting <12 weeks and others ≥12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel pathogens causing wilt disease in ginger plants and confirm the pathogenicity of A. xylosoxidans.
results_summary: The study identified A. xylosoxidans as a novel pathogen causing wilt disease in ginger, with symptoms including yellowing, wilting, and rhizome browning. Pathogenicity tests confirmed the bacterium's role, and yield losses exceeded 20% in affected fields.
population_specificity: Ginger plants (Tongling white ginger variety) in the Yi'an District of Tongling city, China.
effective_dosage: Bacterial suspension at 10^8 CFU/mL, 10 μL injected per plant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of ginger supplementation on reducing circulating levels of inflammatory markers (CRP, hs-CRP, TNF-α, sICAM, and IL-6) in randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant reduction in circulating CRP levels due to ginger supplementation, with a strong effect size (SMD: -5.11). The study included 16 RCTs with 1010 participants, supporting ginger's anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Participants in randomized controlled trials (no specific subpopulation mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ginger supplementation on inflammatory markers and total antioxidant capacity in patients with active ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be a planned trial rather than a completed one.
population_specificity: Patients with active ulcerative colitis (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Ginger and turmeric on quality of life, body composition, bone mineral density (BMD), and osteoporosis-related biomarkers in women with postmenopausal osteoporosis (PMO).
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not provide results, as it is a prospective trial. The outcomes will assess primary endpoints (quality of life, body composition, BMD) and secondary endpoints (osteoporosis-related serum biomarkers and micro-RNAs).
population_specificity: Women with postmenopausal osteoporosis (PMO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of ginger supplementation on markers of inflammatory and oxidative stress, including CRP, TNF-α, IL-6, PGE2, TAC, and MDA.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found statistically significant effects of ginger on reducing serum CRP, TNF-α, IL-6, and MDA levels, as well as increasing TAC. The effect on PGE2 was marginally significant. Subgroup analysis resolved high heterogeneity based on age, duration, dosage, and study quality.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population from included clinical trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of ginger supplementation on blood pressure (BP) through a systematic review and meta-analysis of clinical trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of six randomized clinical trials (345 participants) found that ginger supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure by an average of 6.36 mmHg. The results suggest a beneficial effect, though the confidence interval indicates some variability in the response.
population_specificity: Human participants in clinical trials assessing blood pressure effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ginger supplementation on chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting in adult cancer patients, comparing it to placebo or standard antiemetic medication.
results_summary: Ginger supplementation reduced the likelihood of acute vomiting by 60% at doses ≤1 g/day for durations >3 days, but no association was found with nausea or other related outcomes. The study suggests potential benefits for fatigue but calls for further research with stronger designs.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ginger supplementation on immunity and inflammation-related gene expression in patients with Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Ginger supplementation significantly increased FoxP3 and PPAR-γ gene expression, decreased T-bet and RORγt gene expression, and reduced disease activity scores in RA patients.
population_specificity: Seventy active RA patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ginger on quality of life, disease activity index, and oxidative stress in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: Ginger significantly reduced oxidative stress marker MDA after 6 and 12 weeks, improved disease activity scores at 12 weeks, and enhanced quality of life in UC patients, though it did not affect serum total antioxidant capacity (TAC).
population_specificity: Patients with active mild to moderate ulcerative colitis (n=46).
effective_dosage: 2000 mg/day dried ginger powder in 4 capsules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether nutritional interventions, including ginger supplementation, could reduce cancer-related fatigue (CRF) and inflammation in cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study suggests that ginger supplementation, along with other nutritional interventions like ginseng and probiotics, may improve energy levels in cancer survivors. Dietary patterns reducing inflammation, such as plant-based diets, were also associated with reduced fatigue.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors experiencing cancer-related fatigue (CRF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of ginger to enhance and protect testosterone production in males.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that ginger has been linked to testosterone production enhancement in males, based on various in-vivo and basic research studies since 1991. However, specific results or statistical significance are not detailed.
population_specificity: Males (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-apoptotic, antioxidant, and iron-chelating properties of hesperidin (H) and its potential to prevent ferroptosis in rats.
results_summary: Hesperidin significantly reduced cardiac markers, iron metabolism markers, and oxidative stress markers while increasing antioxidant markers and decreasing caspase-3 expression, demonstrating protective effects against ferroptosis.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanostructured lipid carrier (NLC) gel of hesperidin (HPD) using a quality-by-design (QbD) approach for effective psoriasis treatment.
results_summary: The optimized HPD-NLC gel showed sustained drug release, reduced crystallinity, and improved skin normalization in an imiquimod-induced psoriasis model compared to the drug-loaded gel group.
population_specificity: Imiquimod-induced psoriasis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hesperidin-loaded hydrogel as a photothermal antibacterial dressing for MRSA-infected wound healing.
results_summary: The hesperidin-loaded hydrogel demonstrated strong photothermal antibacterial activity against E. coli, S. aureus, and MRSA, promoted wound closure, reduced inflammation, and enhanced angiogenesis and collagen deposition, outperforming a commercial wound dressing.
population_specificity: MRSA-infected chronic wounds (in vitro and likely in vivo models, though not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin (Hesp) and Hesp-loaded nanoparticles (Hesp-NPs) could protect against acetaminophen (APAP)-induced acute hepatotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Hesp and Hesp-NPs significantly reduced oxidative stress and liver enzyme levels, increased antioxidant markers, and modulated gene expression related to liver protection, with Hesp-NPs showing greater efficacy. Histopathological findings supported these biochemical and molecular improvements.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin (HESP) could prevent streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic liver damage in rats by examining its effects on inflammatory markers, lipid profiles, and liver enzymes.
results_summary: Hesperidin significantly reduced elevated liver enzymes (AST, ALT, LDH), inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β), apoptotic markers (caspase-3), and improved lipid profiles (LDL, triglycerides, total cholesterol) in diabetic rats compared to the untreated STZ group.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats (n=7 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hesperidin could act as an anticancer agent by targeting the c-Myc G-quadruplex (G4) silencer element and modulating c-Myc expression in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Hesperidin demonstrated strong binding to the c-Myc G4 silencer, stabilized the G4 structure, and selectively inhibited the viability of MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells while sparing normal cells. It reduced clonogenic potential, migration, and c-Myc expression, and preclinical studies showed a marked reduction in tumor volume with minimal systemic toxicity.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cells (in vitro) and preclinical models (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the co-delivery of Hesperidin and Alectinib via Nanostructured Lipid Carriers for treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) through inhalation.
results_summary: The optimized ALB-HSD NLC showed improved drug release (2.5-fold higher than suspension), dose-dependent toxicity (IC50 of 73.52 µg/mL for HSD), and enhanced pharmacokinetic performance (1.57-fold higher AUC0-t for HSD). In vivo studies also demonstrated significant results in a syngeneic model.
population_specificity: A549 human lung cell line and syngeneic model (preclinical study).
effective_dosage: 0.5213 μg/mL (HSD in suspension), dose-dependent toxicity noted.
study_duration: 72 hours (in vitro), duration in vivo not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the growth factor release profiles of hesperidin hydrogel and Biodentine to assess their potential in vital pulp therapy.
results_summary: Hesperidin hydrogel demonstrated significantly higher and sustained release of VEGF compared to Biodentine across all time intervals, indicating prolonged regenerative potential. Biodentine showed an initial burst release that declined over time, while hesperidin maintained stable bioactivity.
population_specificity: Extracted human third molars processed into dentin discs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the water solubility of hesperidin by developing solid dispersed systems (SDSs) using centrifugal fibre formation to enhance its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that SDSs of hesperidin increased its water solubility by 150-170 times compared to pure hesperidin, with faster release rates in various pH conditions, confirming the method's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel nanocarrier system for hesperidin to enhance its solubility, bioavailability, and therapeutic effects against otitis media and oxidative stress diseases.
results_summary: The GO-HSP-loaded neem oil double emulsion demonstrated sustained release, significant antibacterial and antifungal activity, antioxidant effects, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines while increasing antioxidant markers in an otitis media rat model. The formulation also showed high cell viability and low cytotoxicity.
population_specificity: In vitro assays and an in vivo rat model of otitis media.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin could counteract malathion-induced ovarian toxicity by modulating miRNA expression, apoptosis, inflammation, and cytokine production.
results_summary: Hesperidin effectively reversed malathion-induced ovarian damage by reducing oxidative stress, apoptosis, and inflammation, while also normalizing miRNA and cytokine levels. The study demonstrated hesperidin's protective role against malathion toxicity.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice (n=40)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which hesperidin alleviates CPT-11-induced diarrhea (CID) in mice, focusing on gut microbiota modulation and the IL-17 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Hesperidin significantly reduced CID severity, improved gut microbiota composition (notably Alistipes, Limosilactobacillus, Rikenella, and Mucispirillum), enhanced intestinal barrier function, and suppressed inflammatory markers like IL-17A and P-p38.
population_specificity: Mice with CPT-11-induced diarrhea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining hesperidin with bleomycin enhances antiproliferative, apoptotic, anti-angiogenic, and autophagic effects in A549 human lung cancer cells.
results_summary: The Hesp + BL combination significantly amplified anticancer effects, including reduced cell viability, inhibited colony formation and migration, lowered VEGF levels, and upregulated apoptotic and autophagic markers compared to either treatment alone. The combination showed synergistic therapeutic potential for lung cancer treatment.
population_specificity: A549 human lung cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the stability and bioavailability of hesperidin (HES) by encapsulating it in nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) and incorporating it into microneedles (MNs) for enhanced anti-obesity effects.
results_summary: The study found that HES-loaded NLCs in microneedles (HES-NLCMNP) improved pharmacokinetics, reduced elimination rates, and enhanced physiological, hematological, and antioxidant markers in treated rats, suggesting a promising platform for obesity management.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential of Hesperidin (HSP) for Mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis (MsPGN) and explore its mechanism of action, particularly its effects on inflammation and immune complex deposition.
results_summary: HSP treatment significantly improved renal function by reducing blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine, and lipid levels, while also decreasing pro-inflammatory cytokines and immune complex deposition. It also downregulated the JAK/STAT pathway, suggesting a potential mechanism for its therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced MsPGN.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin supplementation could reduce systemic inflammation (measured by CRP levels) and improve clinical periodontal parameters in patients with chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: Hesperidin significantly reduced serum CRP levels, indicating an anti-inflammatory effect, but did not improve clinical periodontal parameters (GI, SBI, PD, CAL) compared to placebo. Both groups showed improvements in clinical parameters over time, likely due to scaling and root planing (SRP).
population_specificity: 80 patients (60 males, 20 females) with moderate to severe chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate hesperidin's efficacy as a feed additive for enhancing gastric acid secretion in broilers and to elucidate its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Hesperidin supplementation at 100 mg/Kg and 150 mg/Kg significantly improved growth performance, nutrient utilization, stomach development, and proton pump activity in broilers. Higher doses also increased pepsin activity, pepsinogen levels, and parietal cell numbers.
population_specificity: Newly hatched (1-day-old) broilers.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 150 mg of hesperidin per kg of basal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of 2S-hesperidin (2S-HES) in mitigating dichlorvos (DDVP)-induced hepatic injury in a rat model.
results_summary: 2S-HES partially reversed DDVP-induced hepatic damage by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and improving lipid profiles and enzyme levels. It also attenuated hepatocellular vacuolation and restored antioxidant defenses.
population_specificity: Rats (42 animals, divided into 7 groups of 6 each).
study_duration: 14 days of 2S-HES intervention following 7 days of DDVP administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of hesperidin-loaded silk fibroin peptide nanofibers (SFP/HE NFs) as a treatment for breast cancer, focusing on its anti-tumor activity and mechanism of action.
results_summary: SFP/HE NFs significantly inhibited breast cancer cell proliferation and migration, induced apoptosis and DNA damage, and activated the cGAS-STING pathway. In vivo, SFP/HE NFs reduced tumor growth by 65.9% at 100 mg/kg and enhanced cisplatin's anti-tumor effects while mitigating its nephrotoxicity.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231 and in vivo models (specifics not detailed).
interactions: Enhanced cisplatin's anti-tumor activity and reduced its nephrotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hepatoprotective, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects of Hesperidin against thioacetamide-induced hepatic fibrosis in rats.
results_summary: Hesperidin reduced liver enzyme activities (ALT, AST, ALP), bilirubin, cholesterol, and triglycerides, while improving antioxidant capacity (reduced MDA levels). It also diminished fibrosis markers (CD34, FGF23) and reduced TGF-β and α-SMA expression, indicating antifibrotic effects.
population_specificity: Male albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin could inhibit Mycobacterial phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase (MtPrsA) as a potential therapeutic strategy for tuberculosis.
results_summary: Hesperidin exhibited a mixed inhibition profile against MtPrsA, demonstrating binding stability in molecular dynamics simulations and enzyme inhibition assays, suggesting potential as a TB treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro study targeting Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hesperidin (HSD) could synergistically enhance the cytotoxic effects of cisplatin (Cisp) on HepG2 liver cancer cells while reducing cellular senescence in normal kidney cells.
results_summary: HSD demonstrated cytotoxic effects on HepG2 cells (IC50 321 µM) and enhanced cisplatin's efficacy (combination index < 1). It also reduced cellular senescence in normal kidney cells caused by cisplatin exposure and increased apoptosis in co-treated HepG2 cells.
population_specificity: HepG2 liver cancer cells and Vero normal kidney cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: IC50 of 321 µM for HSD (single-dose assessment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of MSCs combined with MPFF (containing hesperidin) on tissue edema, inflammation, and molecular mechanisms in a hemorrhoid model.
results_summary: The combination of MSCs and MPFF significantly reduced tissue edema, inflammation, TNF-α expression, and MMP-9 activity, while increasing TGF-β expression and collagen type I/III ratio, accelerating wound healing.
population_specificity: Croton oil-induced hemorrhoid mouse models

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the neuropharmacological mechanisms of hesperidin in preventing and treating Alzheimer's disease (AD) through preclinical and limited clinical studies.
results_summary: Hesperidin demonstrated neuroprotective potential by inhibiting Aβ aggregation, enhancing antioxidant defenses, reducing neuroinflammation and apoptosis, improving mitochondrial dysfunction, regulating autophagy, and promoting neurogenesis. Limited clinical trials suggested improvements in cerebral blood flow, cognition, and memory performance.
population_specificity: Preclinical (in vitro and in vivo) and limited human clinical trial participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of hesperidin and hesperetin on liver disorders, focusing on their relationship with inflammation, blood sugar regulation, and blood lipids.
results_summary: Hesperidin and hesperetin demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, showing promise for liver diseases, though their low water solubility limits potential effects. More studies are needed to determine optimal dosage and therapeutic use.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on liver disorders, including metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a blend containing hesperidin, along with AM3 and spermidine, could reduce biological age and improve immune function, redox state, and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement blend, including hesperidin, improved immune function, reduced biological age by 11 years, and decreased oxidative-inflammatory states in participants.
population_specificity: 41 participants aged 30-63 years.
effective_dosage: 50 mg hesperidin (as part of a blend) taken twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate hesperidin's therapeutic effects and molecular mechanisms on cell migration and epithelial-mesenchymal transition in proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR).
results_summary: Hesperidin inhibited cell proliferation, migration, and EMT processes induced by TGF-β2, upregulated epithelial markers (E-cadherin), and downregulated mesenchymal markers (MMP-1, -2, -9, fibronectin, α-SMA, Snail, Slug, ZEB-1). It also increased TIMP-1 and TIMP-2 expression levels.
population_specificity: Human retinal pigment epithelial cells (ARPE-19)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore hesperidin's therapeutic potential in central nervous system (CNS) diseases, particularly stroke, and discuss its bioavailability for clinical application.
results_summary: The study highlights hesperidin's broad biological activities, including neuroprotection, and emphasizes its promising role in treating CNS diseases, especially stroke. It also discusses bioavailability to support clinical use.
population_specificity: Not specified (general CNS disease focus, particularly stroke)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of hesperidin in inhibiting glycolysis and its potential therapeutic effects on colorectal cancer (CRC) cell lines.
results_summary: Hesperidin inhibited CRC cell growth, migration, and glycolysis while promoting apoptosis and altering cell cycles. It also suppressed tumor growth in nude mice and altered metabolic functions.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer (CRC) cell lines (HCT116 and SW620) and nude mice with tumor xenografts.
effective_dosage: In vitro: 0-500 µmol/L; in vivo: 20 mg/kg (low dose) and 60 mg/kg (high dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate Hesperidin from Citrus latifolia as a potential therapeutic agent for lung cancer, focusing on its binding affinity to EGFR and cytotoxic effects.
results_summary: Hesperidin showed strong binding affinity to EGFR (GOLD score: 60.98 kcal/mol) and demonstrated potent inhibitory effects with an IC50 of 34.25 µg/ml, supported by stable molecular dynamics simulations over 100 ns.
population_specificity: In-silico and in-vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
study_duration: Molecular dynamics simulation duration: 100 ns (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of hesperidin (combined with diosmin) on diabetic neuropathy in rats, focusing on nerve regeneration via the FGF21 and galectin-3 pathway.
results_summary: Hesperidin and diosmin treatment improved nerve conduction, motor performance, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammation in diabetic rats, with dose-dependent effects. Histopathological findings showed decreased perineural thickness, indicating nerve regeneration.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-proliferative activity and mechanisms of hesperidin extract on non-small lung cancer cells (A549 and H460) by targeting the miR-34a/PD-L1/NF-κB signalling pathway.
results_summary: Hesperidin extract significantly inhibited proliferation of non-small lung cancer cells, suppressed the NF-κB pathway, upregulated miR-34a and P53, downregulated EGFR and P53, and induced cell cycle arrest at sub-G1 and G2 phases.
population_specificity: Non-small lung cancer cells (A549 and H460) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin and fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) could alleviate diet-induced obesity and related metabolic disorders in mice by modulating gut microbiota.
results_summary: Hesperidin reduced obesity, inflammation, and improved gut integrity in high-fat diet-fed mice, with dose-dependent effects. It also selectively altered gut microbiota composition, promoting beneficial bacteria and inhibiting harmful ones.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Hesperidin as a feed additive in promoting gastrointestinal motility in broilers and to elucidate its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: Hesperidin significantly improved gastric emptying and intestinal transit rates in broilers, particularly at doses of 100mg/Kg and 150mg/Kg. It also modulated gut-brain axis signaling and SCF/C-Kit pathways, with the 150mg/Kg dose showing the most pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Newly hatched (1-day-old) broilers.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 150 mg of hesperidin per kg of basal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a chitosan/hesperidin nanoformulation (Hes-NPs) could enhance the protective effects of hesperidin against doxorubicin-induced nephrotoxicity in mice by improving its bioavailability.
results_summary: Pretreatment with Hes or Hes-NPs reduced doxorubicin-induced nephrotoxicity, with Hes-NPs showing superior effects in lowering kidney damage markers, oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis while enhancing antioxidant activity and protective gene expression.
population_specificity: Male albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Hesperidin (HSD) could mitigate oxidative stress, hippocampal neurogenesis arrest, and apoptosis induced by valproic acid (VPA) in rats.
results_summary: HSD significantly reduced oxidative stress, restored antioxidant enzyme activity, and mitigated VPA-induced cell cycle arrest and apoptotic activity in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hesperidin (HES) could mitigate testicular damage, biochemical changes, and semen quality deterioration in rats exposed to glyphosate (GLP).
